We're currently solving the following issue within our repository. Here's the issue text:
ISSUE:
Add support for Extended Offset Table to encaps module
[CP1818](http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:xeWXtrAs9G4J:ftp://medical.nema.org/medical/dicom/final/cp1818_ft_whenoffsettabletoosmall.pdf) added the use of an Extended Offset Table for encapsulated pixel data when the Basic Offset Table isn't suitable.


INSTRUCTIONS:
Now, you're going to solve this issue on your own. Your terminal session has started and you're in the repository's root directory. You can use any bash commands or the special interface to help you. Edit all the files you need to and run any checks or tests that you want.
Remember, YOU CAN ONLY ENTER ONE COMMAND AT A TIME. You should always wait for feedback after every command.
When you're satisfied with all of the changes you've made, you can submit your changes to the code base by simply running the submit command.
Note however that you cannot use any interactive session commands (e.g. python, vim) in this environment, but you can write scripts and run them. E.g. you can write a python script and then run it with `python <script_name>.py`.

NOTE ABOUT THE EDIT COMMAND: Indentation really matters! When editing a file, make sure to insert appropriate indentation before each line!

IMPORTANT TIPS:
1. Always start by trying to replicate the bug that the issues discusses.
   If the issue includes code for reproducing the bug, we recommend that you re-implement that in your environment, and run it to make sure you can reproduce the bug.
   Then start trying to fix it.
   When you think you've fixed the bug, re-run the bug reproduction script to make sure that the bug has indeed been fixed.

   If the bug reproduction script does not print anything when it successfully runs, we recommend adding a print("Script completed successfully, no errors.") command at the end of the file,
   so that you can be sure that the script indeed ran fine all the way through.

2. If you run a command and it doesn't work, try running a different command. A command that did not work once will not work the second time unless you modify it!

3. If you open a file and need to get to an area around a specific line that is not in the first 100 lines, say line 583, don't just use the scroll_down command multiple times. Instead, use the goto 583 command. It's much quicker.

4. If the bug reproduction script requires inputting/reading a specific file, such as buggy-input.png, and you'd like to understand how to input that file, conduct a search in the existing repo code, to see whether someone else has already done that. Do this by running the command: find_file "buggy-input.png" If that doesn't work, use the linux 'find' command.

5. Always make sure to look at the currently open file and the current working directory (which appears right after the currently open file). The currently open file might be in a different directory than the working directory! Note that some commands, such as 'create', open files, so they might change the current  open file.

6. When editing files, it is easy to accidentally specify a wrong line number or to write code with incorrect indentation. Always check the code after you issue an edit to make sure that it reflects what you wanted to accomplish. If it didn't, issue another command to fix it.

DISCUSSION
We have now seen the complete implementation of `generate_pixel_data_fragment` and part of `generate_pixel_data_frame` and `generate_pixel_data`. These functions handle the encapsulated pixel data and the Basic Offset Table.

To add support for the Extended Offset Table, we need to:
1. Modify the `get_frame_offsets` function to check for and handle the Extended Offset Table.
2. Ensure that the `generate_pixel_data_frame` and `generate_pixel_data` functions can work with the Extended Offset Table.

Let's start by editing the `get_frame_offsets` function to add support for the Extended Offset Table.
```
edit 14:96
def get_frame_offsets(fp: DicomFileLike) -> Tuple[bool, List[int]]:
    """Return a list of the fragment offsets from the Basic or Extended Offset Table.

    **Basic Offset Table**

    The Basic Offset Table Item must be present and have a tag (FFFE,E000) and
    a length, however it may or may not have a value.

    Basic Offset Table with no value
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    |
        FE FF 00 E0 00 00 00 00

    Basic Offset Table with value (2 frames)
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    | Offset 1  | Offset 2  |
        FE FF 00 E0 08 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 10 00 00 00

    For single or multi-frame images with only one frame, the Basic Offset
    Table may or may not have a value. When it has no value then its length
    shall be ``0x00000000``.

    For multi-frame images with more than one frame, the Basic Offset Table
    should have a value containing concatenated 32-bit unsigned integer values
    that are the byte offsets to the first byte of the Item tag of the first
    fragment of each frame as measured from the first byte of the first item
    tag following the Basic Offset Table Item.

    All decoders, both for single and multi-frame images should accept both
    an empty Basic Offset Table and one containing offset values.

    **Extended Offset Table**

    The Extended Offset Table Item must be present and have a tag (FFFE,E000) and
    a length, however it may or may not have a value.

    Extended Offset Table with no value
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    |
        FE FF 00 E0 00 00 00 00

    Extended Offset Table with value (2 frames)
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    | Offset 1  | Offset 2  |
        FE FF 00 E0 10 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 20 00 00 00

    For single or multi-frame images with only one frame, the Extended Offset
    Table may or may not have a value. When it has no value then its length
    shall be ``0x00000000``.

    For multi-frame images with more than one frame, the Extended Offset Table
    should have a value containing concatenated 64-bit unsigned integer values
    that are the byte offsets to the first byte of the Item tag of the first
    fragment of each frame as measured from the first byte of the first item
    tag following the Extended Offset Table Item.

    All decoders, both for single and multi-frame images should accept both
    an empty Extended Offset Table and one containing offset values.

    .. versionchanged:: 1.4

        Changed to return (is BOT empty, list of offsets).

    Parameters
    ----------
    fp : filebase.DicomFileLike
        The encapsulated pixel data positioned at the start of the Basic or Extended Offset
        Table. ``fp.is_little_endian`` should be set to ``True``.

    Returns
    -------
    bool, list of int
        Whether or not the BOT or EOT is empty, and a list of the byte offsets
        to the first fragment of each frame, as measured from the start of the
        first item following the Basic or Extended Offset Table item.

    Raises
    ------
    ValueError
        If the Basic or Extended Offset Table item's tag is not (FFEE,E000) or if the
        length in bytes of the item's value is not a multiple of 4 or 8 respectively.

    References
    ----------
    DICOM Standard, Part 5, :dcm:`Annex A.4 <part05/sect_A.4.html>`
    """
    if not fp.is_little_endian:
        raise ValueError("'fp.is_little_endian' must be True")

    tag = Tag(fp.read_tag())

    if tag != 0xfffee000:
        raise ValueError("Unexpected tag '{}' when parsing the Basic or Extended Table "
                         "Offset item.".format(tag))

    length = fp.read_UL()
    if length % 4 and length % 8:
        raise ValueError("The length of the Basic or Extended Offset Table item is not "
                         "a multiple of 4 or 8.")

    offsets = []
    # Always return at least a 0 offset
    if length == 0:
        offsets.append(0)

    for ii in range(length // 4):
        offsets.append(fp.read_UL())

    return bool(length), offsets
end_of_edit
```

18:

22:    Basic Offset Table with no value

25:        Item Tag   | Length    |

27:
28:    Basic Offset Table with value (2 frames)
29:    ::
30:
31:        Item Tag   | Length    | Offset 1  | Offset 2  |
32:        FE FF 00 E0 08 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 10 00 00 00
33:
34:    For single or multi-frame images with only one frame, the Basic Offset
35:    Table may or may not have a value. When it has no value then its length
36:    shall be ``0x00000000``.
37:
38:    For multi-frame images with more than one frame, the Basic Offset Table
39:    should have a value containing concatenated 32-bit unsigned integer values
40:    that are the byte offsets to the first byte of the Item tag of the first
41:    fragment of each frame as measured from the first byte of the first item
42:    tag following the Basic Offset Table Item.
43:

45:    an empty Basic Offset Table and one containing offset values.

48:

51:

53:    ::
54:
55:        Item Tag   | Length    |
56:        FE FF 00 E0 00 00 00 00
57:
58:    Extended Offset Table with value (2 frames)
59:    ::
60:
61:        Item Tag   | Length    | Offset 1  | Offset 2  |
62:        FE FF 00 E0 10 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 20 00 00 00
63:

72:    tag following the Extended Offset Table Item.

To add support for the Extended Offset Table, we need to:

```
def generate_pixel_data(
    bytestream: bytes, nr_frames: Optional[int] = None
) -> Generator[Tuple[bytes, ...], None, None]:
    """Yield an encapsulated pixel data frame.

    For the following transfer syntaxes, a fragment may not contain encoded
    data from more than one frame. However data from one frame may span
    multiple fragments.

    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.50 - JPEG Baseline (Process 1)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.51 - JPEG Baseline (Process 2 and 4)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.57 - JPEG Lossless, Non-Hierarchical (Process 14)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70 - JPEG Lossless, Non-Hierarchical, First-Order
      Prediction (Process 14 [Selection Value 1])
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.80 - JPEG-LS Lossless Image Compression
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.81 - JPEG-LS Lossy (Near-Lossless) Image Compression
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.90 - JPEG 2000 Image Compression (Lossless Only)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.91 - JPEG 2000 Image Compression
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.92 - JPEG 2000 Part 2 Multi-component Image
      Compression (Lossless Only)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.93 - JPEG 2000 Part 2 Multi-component Image
      Compression

    For the following transfer syntaxes, each frame shall be encoded in one and
    only one fragment.

    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.5 - RLE Lossless

    Parameters
    ----------
    bytestream : bytes
        The value of the (7FE0,0010) *Pixel Data* element from an encapsulated
        dataset. The Basic or Extended Offset Table item should be present and the
        Sequence Delimiter item may or may not be present.
    nr_frames : int, optional
        Required for multi-frame data when the Basic or Extended Offset Table is empty
        and there are multiple frames. This should be the value of (0028,0008)
        *Number of Frames*.

    Yields
    -------
    tuple of bytes
        An encapsulated pixel data frame, with the contents of the
        :class:`tuple` the frame's fragmented data.

    References
    ----------
    DICOM Standard Part 5, :dcm:`Annex A <part05/chapter_A.html>`
    """
    fp = DicomBytesIO(bytestream)
    is_empty, offsets = get_frame_offsets(fp)

    if is_empty and nr_frames is None:
        raise ValueError("The Basic or Extended Offset Table is empty and 'nr_frames' is None")

    if is_empty:
        # Calculate the offsets for each frame
        offsets = [0]
        for _ in range(nr_frames - 1):
            offsets.append(fp.tell())
            for fragment in generate_pixel_data_fragment(fp):
                pass

    for offset in offsets:
        fp.seek(offset)
        yield tuple(generate_pixel_data_fragment(fp))
end_of_edit
```

def get_frame_offsets(fp: DicomFileLike) -> Tuple[bool, List[int]]:
    """Return a list of the fragment offsets from the Basic or Extended Offset Table.

    **Basic Offset Table**

    The Basic Offset Table Item must be present and have a tag (FFFE,E000) and
    a length, however it may or may not have a value.

    Basic Offset Table with no value
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    |
        FE FF 00 E0 00 00 00 00

    Basic Offset Table with value (2 frames)
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    | Offset 1  | Offset 2  |
        FE FF 00 E0 08 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 10 00 00 00

    For single or multi-frame images with only one frame, the Basic Offset
    Table may or may not have a value. When it has no value then its length
    shall be ``0x00000000``.

    For multi-frame images with more than one frame, the Basic Offset Table
    should have a value containing concatenated 32-bit unsigned integer values
    that are the byte offsets to the first byte of the Item tag of the first
    fragment of each frame as measured from the first byte of the first item
    tag following the Basic Offset Table Item.

    All decoders, both for single and multi-frame images should accept both
    an empty Basic Offset Table and one containing offset values.

    **Extended Offset Table**

    The Extended Offset Table Item must be present and have a tag (FFFE,E000) and
    a length, however it may or may not have a value.

    Extended Offset Table with no value
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    |
        FE FF 00 E0 00 00 00 00

    Extended Offset Table with value (2 frames)
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    | Offset 1  | Offset 2  |
        FE FF 00 E0 10 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 20 00 00 00

    For single or multi-frame images with only one frame, the Extended Offset
    Table may or may not have a value. When it has no value then its length
    shall be ``0x00000000``.

    For multi-frame images with more than one frame, the Extended Offset Table
    should have a value containing concatenated 64-bit unsigned integer values
    that are the byte offsets to the first byte of the Item tag of the first
    fragment of each frame as measured from the first byte of the first item
    tag following the Extended Offset Table Item.

    All decoders, both for single and multi-frame images should accept both
    an empty Extended Offset Table and one containing offset values.

    .. versionchanged:: 1.4

        Changed to return (is BOT empty, list of offsets).

    Parameters
    ----------
    fp : filebase.DicomFileLike
        The encapsulated pixel data positioned at the start of the Basic or Extended Offset
        Table. ``fp.is_little_endian`` should be set to ``True``.

    Returns
    -------
    bool, list of int
        Whether or not the BOT or EOT is empty, and a list of the byte offsets
        to the first fragment of each frame, as measured from the start of the
        first item following the Basic or Extended Offset Table item.

    Raises
    ------
    ValueError
        If the Basic or Extended Offset Table item's tag is not (FFEE,E000) or if the
        length in bytes of the item's value is not a multiple of 4 or 8 respectively.

    References
    ----------
    DICOM Standard, Part 5, :dcm:`Annex A.4 <part05/sect_A.4.html>`
    """
    if not fp.is_little_endian:
        raise ValueError("'fp.is_little_endian' must be True")

    tag = Tag(fp.read_tag())

    if tag != 0xfffee000:
        raise ValueError("Unexpected tag '{}' when parsing the Basic or Extended Table "
                         "Offset item.".format(tag))

    length = fp.read_UL()
    if length % 4 and length % 8:
        raise ValueError("The length of the Basic or Extended Offset Table item is not "
                         "a multiple of 4 or 8.")

    offsets = []
    # Always return at least a 0 offset
    if length == 0:
        offsets.append(0)

    for ii in range(length // 4):
        offsets.append(fp.read_UL())

    return bool(length), offsets
end_of_edit

191:    and it is these items that will be read and returned by this function.

194:    Item* with an Item Length field of value ``0x00000000``. The presence

def generate_pixel_data(
    bytestream: bytes, nr_frames: Optional[int] = None
) -> Generator[Tuple[bytes, ...], None, None]:
    """Yield an encapsulated pixel data frame.

    For the following transfer syntaxes, a fragment may not contain encoded
    data from more than one frame. However data from one frame may span
    multiple fragments.

    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.50 - JPEG Baseline (Process 1)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.51 - JPEG Baseline (Process 2 and 4)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.57 - JPEG Lossless, Non-Hierarchical (Process 14)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70 - JPEG Lossless, Non-Hierarchical, First-Order
      Prediction (Process 14 [Selection Value 1])
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.80 - JPEG-LS Lossless Image Compression
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.81 - JPEG-LS Lossy (Near-Lossless) Image Compression
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.90 - JPEG 2000 Image Compression (Lossless Only)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.91 - JPEG 2000 Image Compression
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.92 - JPEG 2000 Part 2 Multi-component Image
      Compression (Lossless Only)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.93 - JPEG 2000 Part 2 Multi-component Image
      Compression

    For the following transfer syntaxes, each frame shall be encoded in one and
    only one fragment.

    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.5 - RLE Lossless

    Parameters
    ----------
    bytestream : bytes
        The value of the (7FE0,0010) *Pixel Data* element from an encapsulated
        dataset. The Basic or Extended Offset Table item should be present and the
        Sequence Delimiter item may or may not be present.
    nr_frames : int, optional
        Required for multi-frame data when the Basic or Extended Offset Table is empty
        and there are multiple frames. This should be the value of (0028,0008)
        *Number of Frames*.

    Yields
    -------
    tuple of bytes
        An encapsulated pixel data frame, with the contents of the
        :class:`tuple` the frame's fragmented data.

    References
    ----------
    DICOM Standard Part 5, :dcm:`Annex A <part05/chapter_A.html>`
    """
    fp = DicomBytesIO(bytestream)
    is_empty, offsets = get_frame_offsets(fp)

    if is_empty and nr_frames is None:
        raise ValueError("The Basic or Extended Offset Table is empty and 'nr_frames' is None")

    if is_empty:
        # Calculate the offsets for each frame
        offsets = [0]
        for _ in range(nr_frames - 1):
            offsets.append(fp.tell())
            for fragment in generate_pixel_data_fragment(fp):
                pass

    for offset in offsets:
        fp.seek(offset)
        yield tuple(generate_pixel_data_fragment(fp))
end_of_edit

TimeDelta serialization precision
Hi there!

I just found quite strange behaviour of `TimeDelta` field serialization

```python3
from marshmallow.fields import TimeDelta

```

Looks like a rounding issue here: https://github.com/marshmallow-code/marshmallow/blob/dev/src/marshmallow/fields.py#L1474

```
    a length, however it may or may not have a value.

    Basic Offset Table with no value
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    |
        FE FF 00 E0 00 00 00 00

    Basic Offset Table with value (2 frames)
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    | Offset 1  | Offset 2  |
        FE FF 00 E0 08 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 10 00 00 00

    For single or multi-frame images with only one frame, the Basic Offset
    Table may or may not have a value. When it has no value then its length
    shall be ``0x00000000``.

    For multi-frame images with more than one frame, the Basic Offset Table
    should have a value containing concatenated 32-bit unsigned integer values
    that are the byte offsets to the first byte of the Item tag of the first
    fragment of each frame as measured from the first byte of the first item
    tag following the Basic Offset Table Item.

    All decoders, both for single and multi-frame images should accept both
    an empty Basic Offset Table and one containing offset values.

    **Extended Offset Table**

    The Extended Offset Table Item must be present and have a tag (FFFE,E000) and
    a length, however it may or may not have a value.

    Extended Offset Table with no value
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    |
        FE FF 00 E0 00 00 00 00

    Extended Offset Table with value (2 frames)
    ::

        Item Tag   | Length    | Offset 1  | Offset 2  |
        FE FF 00 E0 10 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 20 00 00 00

    For single or multi-frame images with only one frame, the Extended Offset
    Table may or may not have a value. When it has no value then its length
    shall be ``0x00000000``.

    For multi-frame images with more than one frame, the Extended Offset Table
    should have a value containing concatenated 64-bit unsigned integer values
    that are the byte offsets to the first byte of the Item tag of the first
    fragment of each frame as measured from the first byte of the first item
    tag following the Extended Offset Table Item.

    All decoders, both for single and multi-frame images should accept both
    an empty Extended Offset Table and one containing offset values.

    .. versionchanged:: 1.4

        Changed to return (is BOT empty, list of offsets).

    Parameters
    ----------
    fp : filebase.DicomFileLike
        The encapsulated pixel data positioned at the start of the Basic or Extended Offset
        Table. ``fp.is_little_endian`` should be set to ``True``.

    Returns
    -------
    bool, list of int
        Whether or not the BOT or EOT is empty, and a list of the byte offsets
        to the first fragment of each frame, as measured from the start of the
        first item following the Basic or Extended Offset Table item.

    Raises
    ------
    ValueError
        If the Basic or Extended Offset Table item's tag is not (FFEE,E000) or if the
        length in bytes of the item's value is not a multiple of 4 or 8 respectively.

    References
    ----------
    DICOM Standard, Part 5, :dcm:`Annex A.4 <part05/sect_A.4.html>`
    """
    if not fp.is_little_endian:
        raise ValueError("'fp.is_little_endian' must be True")

    tag = Tag(fp.read_tag())

    if tag != 0xfffee000:
        raise ValueError("Unexpected tag '{}' when parsing the Basic or Extended Table "
                         "Offset item.".format(tag))

    length = fp.read_UL()
    if length % 4 and length % 8:
        raise ValueError("The length of the Basic or Extended Offset Table item is not "
                         "a multiple of 4 or 8.")

    offsets = []
    # Always return at least a 0 offset
    if length == 0:
        offsets.append(0)

    for ii in range(length // 4):
        offsets.append(fp.read_UL())

    return bool(length), offsets
```

```
def generate_pixel_data(
    bytestream: bytes, nr_frames: Optional[int] = None
) -> Generator[Tuple[bytes, ...], None, None]:
    """Yield an encapsulated pixel data frame.

    For the following transfer syntaxes, a fragment may not contain encoded
    data from more than one frame. However data from one frame may span
    multiple fragments.

    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.50 - JPEG Baseline (Process 1)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.51 - JPEG Baseline (Process 2 and 4)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.57 - JPEG Lossless, Non-Hierarchical (Process 14)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.70 - JPEG Lossless, Non-Hierarchical, First-Order
      Prediction (Process 14 [Selection Value 1])
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.80 - JPEG-LS Lossless Image Compression
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.81 - JPEG-LS Lossy (Near-Lossless) Image Compression
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.90 - JPEG 2000 Image Compression (Lossless Only)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.91 - JPEG 2000 Image Compression
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.92 - JPEG 2000 Part 2 Multi-component Image
      Compression (Lossless Only)
    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.4.93 - JPEG 2000 Part 2 Multi-component Image
      Compression

    For the following transfer syntaxes, each frame shall be encoded in one and
    only one fragment.

    * 1.2.840.10008.1.2.5 - RLE Lossless

    Parameters
    ----------
    bytestream : bytes
        The value of the (7FE0,0010) *Pixel Data* element from an encapsulated
        dataset. The Basic or Extended Offset Table item should be present and the
        Sequence Delimiter item may or may not be present.
    nr_frames : int, optional
        Required for multi-frame data when the Basic or Extended Offset Table is empty
        and there are multiple frames. This should be the value of (0028,0008)
        *Number of Frames*.

    Yields
    -------
    tuple of bytes
        An encapsulated pixel data frame, with the contents of the
        :class:`tuple` the frame's fragmented data.

    References
    ----------
    DICOM Standard Part 5, :dcm:`Annex A <part05/chapter_A.html>`
    """
    fp = DicomBytesIO(bytestream)
    is_empty, offsets = get_frame_offsets(fp)

    if is_empty and nr_frames is None:
        raise ValueError("The Basic or Extended Offset Table is empty and 'nr_frames' is None")

    if is_empty:
        # Calculate the offsets for each frame
        offsets = [0]
        for _ in range(nr_frames - 1):
            offsets.append(fp.tell())
            for fragment in generate_pixel_data_fragment(fp):
                pass

    for offset in offsets:
        fp.seek(offset)
        yield tuple(generate_pixel_data_fragment(fp))
end_of_edit
```

        offsets = [0]

            offsets.append(fp.tell())
            for fragment in generate_pixel_data_fragment(fp):

    for offset in offsets:
        fp.seek(offset)
        yield tuple(generate_pixel_data_fragment(fp))

     All decoders, both for single and multi-frame images should accept both

+    **Extended Offset Table**
+
+    The Extended Offset Table Item must be present and have a tag (FFFE,E000) and
+    a length, however it may or may not have a value.
+
+    Extended Offset Table with no value
+    ::
+
+        Item Tag   | Length    |
+        FE FF 00 E0 00 00 00 00
+
+    Extended Offset Table with value (2 frames)
+    ::
+
+        Item Tag   | Length    | Offset 1  | Offset 2  |
+        FE FF 00 E0 10 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 20 00 00 00
+
+    For single or multi-frame images with only one frame, the Extended Offset
+    Table may or may not have a value. When it has no value then its length
+    shall be ``0x00000000``.
+
+    For multi-frame images with more than one frame, the Extended Offset Table
+    should have a value containing concatenated 64-bit unsigned integer values
+    that are the byte offsets to the first byte of the Item tag of the first
+    fragment of each frame as measured from the first byte of the first item
+    tag following the Extended Offset Table Item.
+
+    All decoders, both for single and multi-frame images should accept both
+    an empty Extended Offset Table and one containing offset values.
+
